**Proposition:** Let $Q$ be a nonempty quasigroup.

I\) The following conditions are equivalent. $$\begin{aligned}
(x(yz))x &=& (xy)(zx) \qquad\text{for all } x,y,z\in Q \\
((xy)z)y &=& x(y(zy)) \qquad\text{for all } x,y,z\in Q \\
(xz)(yx) &=& x((zy)x) \qquad\text{for all } x,y,z\in Q \\
((yz)y)x &=& y(z(yx)) \qquad\text{for all } x,y,z\in Q\end{aligned}$$

II\) If $Q$ satisfies those conditions, then $Q$ has an identity element
(i.e., $Q$ is a loop).

For a proof, we refer the reader to the two references. Kunen in \[1\]
shows that that any of the four conditions implies the existence of an
identity element. And Bol and Bruck \[2\] show that the four conditions
are equivalent for loops.

**Definition:** A nonempty quasigroup satisfying the conditions (1)–(4)
is called a Moufang quasigroup or, equivalently, a Moufang loop (after
Ruth Moufang, 1905–1977).

The 16-element set of unit octonions over $\mathbb{Z}$ is an example of
a nonassociative Moufang loop. Other examples appear in projective
geometry, coding theory, and elsewhere.

**References**

\[1\] Kenneth Kunen, [*Moufang Quasigroups*]{}, J. Algebra 83 (1996)
231–234. (A preprint in PostScript format is available from Kunen’s
website: .)

\[2\] R. H. Bruck, [*A Survey of Binary Systems,*]{} Springer-Verlag,
1958.
